metadata.description: English grammar rules with Portuguese comparison

rules.name: Present Simple
rules.english_explanation: Used for habits, routines, facts, and general truths. Form: subject + base verb (add -s/-es for third person singular)
rules.portuguese_explanation: Usado para hábitos, rotinas, fatos e verdades gerais. Similar ao Presente do Indicativo em português.
similarities: Both express habitual actions
Both express general truths
Both can express scheduled future events
differences: English requires auxiliary 'do/does' for questions and negatives
English adds -s/-es only to third person singular
Portuguese conjugates for all persons
common_mistakes: Forgetting the -s in third person: 'She work' instead of 'She works'
Using 'do' with 'be': 'Do you are?' instead of 'Are you?'
memory_tips: Remember: 'does' already has the S, so verb stays base form

rules.name: Present Continuous
rules.english_explanation: Used for actions happening now or around now. Form: subject + am/is/are + verb-ing
rules.portuguese_explanation: Usado para ações acontecendo agora. Similar ao 'estar + gerúndio' em português.
similarities: Both express actions in progress
Both use a form of 'to be' + continuous form
differences: English uses -ing ending
Portuguese uses -ando, -endo, -indo endings
English also uses it for future arrangements
common_mistakes: Forgetting the verb 'to be': 'I working' instead of 'I am working'
Using with stative verbs: 'I am knowing' instead of 'I know'
memory_tips: Stative verbs (know, want, like) usually don't use -ing

rules.name: Simple Past
rules.english_explanation: Used for completed actions in the past. Regular verbs: add -ed. Irregular verbs: memorize forms.
rules.portuguese_explanation: Usado para ações completas no passado. Similar ao Pretérito Perfeito.
similarities: Both express completed past actions
Both have regular and irregular forms
differences: English regular verbs all end in -ed
English uses 'did' for questions and negatives
Portuguese has different conjugations for each person
common_mistakes: Using base form with did: 'Did you went?' instead of 'Did you go?'
Wrong irregular forms: 'goed' instead of 'went'

rules.name: Present Perfect
rules.english_explanation: Used for past actions with present relevance, experiences, or actions from past to now. Form: have/has + past participle
rules.portuguese_explanation: Conecta passado e presente. Português usa pretérito perfeito simples, mas o significado é diferente.
similarities: Uses past participle form like Portuguese compound tenses
differences: Portuguese doesn't distinguish between simple past and present perfect
English present perfect cannot be used with specific past times
common_mistakes: Using with specific past time: 'I have seen him yesterday' instead of 'I saw him yesterday'
Confusing with simple past
memory_tips: No specific time? Use present perfect
Keywords: ever, never, just, already, yet, since, for

examples.english: I have lived here for 5 years.
Have you ever been to Japan?

common_errors.explanation: Cannot use present perfect with specific past time

rules.name: Future with Will
rules.english_explanation: Used for predictions, spontaneous decisions, promises, and offers. Form: will + base verb
rules.portuguese_explanation: Expressa futuro. Similar ao Futuro Simples em português.
similarities: Both express future actions
Both can express predictions and promises
differences: English 'will' doesn't change with person
Portuguese conjugates the verb for each person
common_mistakes: Adding -s to will: 'He wills go' instead of 'He will go'
Using 'will' after 'if' in conditionals

examples.portuguese: Eu vou ajudá-lo / Eu te ajudarei.

rules.name: Articles (a/an/the)
rules.english_explanation: A/AN for non-specific (a before consonant sound, an before vowel sound). THE for specific or unique things.
rules.portuguese_explanation: Artigos em inglês funcionam de forma diferente do português.
similarities: Both languages have definite and indefinite articles
differences: English uses sound, not letter: 'an hour' but 'a university'
English often omits article with uncountable nouns
No article with most proper nouns in English
common_mistakes: Using 'a' before vowel sound: 'a apple' instead of 'an apple'
Using 'the' with general concepts: 'The life is beautiful' instead of 'Life is beautiful'
memory_tips: Listen to the SOUND, not the letter
A UNIVERSITY (yoo- sound), AN HOUR (silent h)

rules.name: Comparative Adjectives
rules.english_explanation: Short adjectives: add -er. Long adjectives: use 'more'. Always use 'than' for comparison.
rules.portuguese_explanation: Comparativos em inglês têm duas formas dependendo do tamanho do adjetivo.
similarities: Both express comparison between two things
differences: English has two forms (-er or more)
Portuguese always uses 'mais' + adjective
common_mistakes: Double comparative: 'more bigger' instead of 'bigger'
Using -er with long adjectives: 'beautifuler' instead of 'more beautiful'

examples.portuguese: Ela é mais alta que eu.

common_errors.incorrect: He is more tall than me.

rules.name: Superlative Adjectives
rules.english_explanation: Short adjectives: the + adjective-est. Long adjectives: the most + adjective.
similarities: Both express the highest degree
differences: English always requires 'the'
Portuguese may use 'o mais' or suffix '-íssimo'
common_mistakes: Forgetting 'the': 'He is tallest' instead of 'He is the tallest'
Double superlative: 'the most biggest'
memory_tips: Same irregulars: best, worst, most, least

examples.portuguese: Ela é a aluna mais inteligente.

common_errors.incorrect: He is tallest in the class.
common_errors.correct: He is the tallest in the class.

rules.name: Modal Verbs (can/could/should/must)
rules.english_explanation: Modal verbs express ability, possibility, permission, obligation. Always followed by base verb.
rules.portuguese_explanation: Verbos modais em inglês são invariáveis e sempre seguidos do infinitivo sem 'to'.
similarities: Both express modality (ability, obligation, etc.)
differences: English modals never change form (no -s, no -ed)
English modals don't use 'to' before main verb
common_mistakes: Adding -s: 'She cans swim' instead of 'She can swim'
Using 'to': 'I must to go' instead of 'I must go'
memory_tips: CAN = ability, SHOULD = advice, MUST = obligation

rules.name: Conditional (First)
rules.english_explanation: Real/possible situations. If + present simple, will + base verb.
rules.portuguese_explanation: Condicionais reais. Em português: Se + presente/futuro.
similarities: Both express possible future conditions
differences: English uses present in 'if' clause, not future
Portuguese can use future in 'se' clause
common_mistakes: Using will in if-clause: 'If I will see him' instead of 'If I see him'
memory_tips: Comma after if-clause when it comes first

examples.english: If it rains, I will stay home.
examples.portuguese: Se chover, eu ficarei em casa.

examples.english: I will call you if I have time.
examples.portuguese: Eu te ligarei se eu tiver tempo.

common_errors.incorrect: If I will go, I will call you.
common_errors.correct: If I go, I will call you.
common_errors.explanation: Don't use will in the if-clause

rules.name: Question Formation
rules.english_explanation: Yes/No questions: auxiliary + subject + verb. Wh- questions: Wh-word + auxiliary + subject + verb.
rules.portuguese_explanation: Perguntas em inglês requerem inversão ou auxiliar.
similarities: Both use question words (what, where, when, etc.)
differences: English requires auxiliary verbs (do/does/did) for most verbs
Portuguese often just changes intonation
common_mistakes: Missing auxiliary: 'You like coffee?' instead of 'Do you like coffee?'
Word order: 'What you want?' instead of 'What do you want?'

rules.name: Subject-Verb Agreement
rules.english_explanation: Singular subjects take singular verbs, plural subjects take plural verbs. Third person singular adds -s/-es in present.
rules.portuguese_explanation: Concordância verbal existe em português também, mas inglês é mais simples.
similarities: Both require verb to agree with subject
differences: English only changes third person singular in present
Portuguese conjugates for all persons and tenses
common_mistakes: Collective nouns: 'The team are' (UK) vs 'The team is' (US)
Everyone/everybody takes singular verb
memory_tips: Either...or: verb agrees with closer subject

rules.name: Prepositions of Time (in/on/at)
rules.english_explanation: AT for specific times and holidays. ON for days and dates. IN for months, years, seasons, longer periods.
rules.portuguese_explanation: Preposições de tempo em inglês são diferentes do português.
similarities: Both languages use prepositions with time expressions
differences: English uses different prepositions than Portuguese might suggest
Rules are more fixed in English
common_mistakes: Using 'in' for days: 'in Monday' instead of 'on Monday'
Using 'on' for years: 'on 2024' instead of 'in 2024'
memory_tips: AT = point (at 3pm, at night, at Christmas)
IN = container/period (in July, in 2024, in the morning)

examples.english: at 5 o'clock / on Monday / in January
examples.portuguese: às 5 horas / na segunda-feira / em janeiro

rules.name: Prepositions of Place (in/on/at)
rules.english_explanation: IN for enclosed spaces. ON for surfaces. AT for specific points/addresses.
rules.portuguese_explanation: Preposições de lugar em inglês seguem regras diferentes do português.
similarities: Both express location
differences: English differentiates between enclosed (in), surface (on), and point (at)
Portuguese uses 'em' for many situations where English uses different prepositions
common_mistakes: 'in the bus' instead of 'on the bus'
'at home' vs 'in my home' (both correct but different use)
memory_tips: IN = 3D (in the room, in the car)
ON = 2D surface (on the table, on the bus)
AT = point (at the door, at 123 Main St)

examples.english: The book is in the box / on the table / at the door.
examples.portuguese: O livro está na caixa / na mesa / na porta.

rules.name: Countable vs Uncountable Nouns
rules.english_explanation: Countable nouns have singular/plural forms and use a/an/numbers. Uncountable nouns use no article or some/much.
rules.portuguese_explanation: Inglês distingue mais claramente entre contáveis e incontáveis.
similarities: Both languages have this distinction
differences: English is stricter about article usage with uncountables
Some nouns are uncountable in English but countable in Portuguese (information, advice, furniture)
common_mistakes: 'an information' instead of 'some information'
'many water' instead of 'much water'
'advices' instead of 'advice'
memory_tips: Uncountable: information, advice, news, furniture, luggage, money
Use MUCH/LITTLE with uncountable, MANY/FEW with countable
Some uncountables can be made countable: 'a piece of advice'

examples.english: I have two pieces of luggage.

common_errors.correct: I have a lot of information.
